answers.answer: You could try asking him why he thinks it's a myth?  Does he accept you for who you are?  Does he accept that you have problems interacting with people your own age group?  Is it just a problem he has with having a name or a label put on it or does he have problems accepting you for whom you are?There are lots of books you could share with him.  Or websites.  if he doesn't read them (my dad never read anything I sent him about my own issues), try not to take it personally.  Some men can be stubborn and not wanting to admit things in life aren't perfect, especially the closer they are to them.  He may not emotionally be able to handle you having aspergers, so if he denies that you have it, he doesn't have to deal with that emotion.  Picture a 3 or 4 year old child who wants to ignore their parents and they cover their ears and start screaming or babbling incoherently "wah wah wah wah" so they can't hear what their parents are saying.  If you don't hear it, it isn't true, right?Sorry you have a father who doesn't believe you.  Wish I could help you.  I know that getting fathers to understand you is important.  I have lupus and diabetes and my dad acknowledges the diabetes (he has diabetes himself) but the lupus portion... he thinks the aching joints and fatigue are all in my head and that I'm just a hypochondriac.  I've had lupus since I was about 18, though was not diagnosed until I was around 28 or so.  I'm now in my mid 30s.  It still hurts when he can say things like "it's all in your head" or doesn't want to hear any of anything.  I had to give up trying to convince him.  I know my condition is quite different from autism, but having to deal with a father who won't acknowledge limits that I have (my limits are physical)... well, it is a hard road in life.  But in addition to having him accept you for who you are, you have to accept him for who he is.  And if that's a stubborn idiot who won't listen, well, you have to love him regardless.  At least that's what it's like with my own dad.
